gen_note:
**Clinical Note:**

**Patient Name:** [Patient's Name]  
**Date:** 10/9/2025  
**Chief Complaint:** Worsening chronic hypertension

**History of Present Illness:**  
The patient presents with a history of chronic hypertension, previously managed with hydrochlorothiazide and Valsartan for 10 years. Recently, the patient's systolic blood pressure has exceeded 200 mmHg, leading to an emergency department visit for headache and malaise. Despite treatment and discharge, the patient returned to the emergency department 5 days later with difficulty finding words, blurred vision, and tingling in the lower extremities. Blood pressure on presentation was 216/81 mmHg. 

**Workup and Findings:**  
- No acute intracranial process or carotid stenosis was identified.
- Echocardiography showed mild concentric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved ejection fraction.
- Blood pressure remained refractory despite treatment with five antihypertensive agents and esmolol infusion.
- Renal artery ultrasound indicated renal artery stenosis with flow at the arterial origin measuring 350 cm/s on the right and 208 cm/s on the left.
- No history of kidney disease or elevated creatinine levels.

**Consultations and Procedures:**  
- Vascular surgery consultation revealed weak but palpable femoral pulses and an audible abdominal aortic bruit. Ankle-brachial index measurements were deferred, and an angiogram was scheduled.
- Aortography performed the following day showed widely patent renal arteries but significant stenosis at the distal thoracic aorta extending into the abdominal aorta.
- The degree of stenosis was greater than 90%, with a pressure gradient between the upper extremity and intra-aortic measurements exceeding 100 mmHg.
- CTA confirmed a stenosis 1.3 cm proximal to the celiac origin measuring 5 mm.

**Plan:**  
The patient will be consulted with other specialists to develop a comprehensive management plan. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the patient's condition and response to treatment.
standard_note:
A 60-year-old female presented to the outpatient cardiology clinic for evaluation of worsening chronic hypertension for which she had been on hydrochlorothiazide/Valsartan for 10 years. Her systolic blood pressure exceeded 200 mmHg in the office, and aggressive medical therapy was initiated in the outpatient setting. She returned to the emergency department the following day with headache and malaise and systolic blood pressure above 200 mmHg for which she was treated and discharged.
She returned to the emergency department again 5 days later, this time with complaints of word finding difficulty, blurred vision, and lower extremity tingling. Her blood pressure on presentation was 216/81 mmHg. She was admitted, and workup demonstrated no acute intracranial process or carotid stenosis. Echocardiography revealed mild concentric left ventricular hypertrophy with a preserved ejection fraction. Her blood pressure continued to be refractory to medical therapy despite five antihypertensive agents and eventual initiation of an esmolol infusion. A renal artery ultrasound identified renal artery stenosis with flow at the arterial origin measuring 350 cm/s on the right and 208 cm/s on the left (); flow velocity in the supraceliac aorta was also noted to be elevated. She had no history of kidney disease and no elevation of her creatinine. Vascular surgery was consulted and a history of lower extremity claudication was elicited. On exam she had weak but palpable femoral pulses and an audible abdominal aortic bruit; ankle-brachial index measurements were deferred and the patient was scheduled for angiogram.
The patient underwent aortography the following day and on selective angiography the renal arteries were found to be widely patent. Significant stenosis was identified at the distal thoracic aorta extending into the abdominal aorta but terminating proximal to the celiac trunk. The degree of stenosis was deemed to be greater than 90% and a pressure gradient between the upper extremity and intra-aortic measurements exceeded 100 mmHg. CTA was subsequently performed to evaluate the extent of the lesion and confirmed a stenosis 1.3 cm proximal to the celiac origin measuring 5 mm at its narrowest point (Figures and ). The patient underwent arteriogram; the stenosis was successfully navigated and a Protege 14 × 40 x 12 mm nitinol stent (Medtronic Vascular, Santa Rosa CA) was delivered followed by a 10 mm postdilation balloon. A completion arteriogram demonstrated excellent flow across the stent.
After stenting, the patients' systolic blood pressure was 140-160 mmHg, and she experienced resolution of her lower extremity claudication. She was discharged from the hospital on Aspirin and Plavix and a blood pressure regimen consisting of lisinopril, hydralazine, amlodipine, and carvedilol.
She was lost to follow-up until two years later when she returned to the hospital with a blood pressure of 220/85 mmHg, with complaints of chest discomfort. CTA demonstrated stenosis in the distal portion of the aortic stent. An angiogram was performed, and the stent was ballooned to 12 mm. Pressure gradient measurements taken before and after dilatation decreased from 60 mmHg to 20 mmHg. On follow-up one year later, she continued to experience excellent blood pressure control.
ozwell-s1: The two notes are essentially the same, with minor differences in wording and structure. Both describe the same clinical scenario involving a patient with worsening chronic hypertension, a history of hypertension managed with hydrochlorothiazide and Valsartan, and recent episodes of extremely high blood pressure. They both detail the patient's symptoms, workup findings, consultations, and the treatment plan, including the discovery of significant stenosis in the aorta and subsequent stenting procedure. The follow-up and outcomes are also consistent across both notes.

standard_note:
**Clinical Note:**

**Date:** 10/9/2025  
**Time:** 3:05 PM  
**Patient:** [Patient's Name]  
**Doctor:** [Doctor's Name]  
**Reason for Visit:** Evaluation of worsening chronic hypertension

**History:**
The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension, managed with hydrochlorothiazide and Valsartan. Recently, the patient's systolic blood pressure has exceeded 200 mmHg, leading to an emergency department visit for headache and malaise. The patient was treated and discharged but returned five days later with difficulty finding words, blurred vision, and tingling in the lower extremities. Blood pressure at that time was 216/81 mmHg.

**Workup:**
- No acute intracranial process or carotid stenosis was found.
- Echocardiography showed mild concentric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved ejection fraction.
- Despite medical therapy, including five antihypertensive agents and an esmolol infusion, blood pressure remained refractory.
- Renal artery ultrasound indicated renal artery stenosis with flow at the arterial origin measuring 350 cm/s on the right and 208 cm/s on the left.
- No history of kidney disease or elevated creatinine levels.

**Consultations and Findings:**
- Vascular surgery consultation revealed weak but palpable femoral pulses and an audible abdominal aortic bruit. Ankle-brachial index measurements were deferred, and an angiogram was scheduled.
- Aortography showed widely patent renal arteries but significant stenosis at the distal thoracic aorta extending into the abdominal aorta.
- Stenosis was greater than 90%, with a pressure gradient between the upper extremity and intra-aortic measurements exceeding 100 mmHg.
- CTA confirmed stenosis 1.3 cm proximal to the celiac origin, measuring 5 mm.

**Plan:**
The patient will be followed up regularly, and a multidisciplinary team will be consulted to develop a comprehensive management plan. Further interventions will be considered based on the extent of the stenosis and the patient's response to ongoing treatment.
ozwell-s1: The two clinical notes are very similar. They both describe the same patient's condition and medical history, focusing on the evaluation of worsening chronic hypertension. Both notes include details about the patient's history of hypertension, recent symptoms, and emergency department visits. They also outline the workup and findings, such as the results of echocardiography, renal artery ultrasound, and aortography, as well as the consultations and findings from vascular surgery. The plans in both notes involve consulting with specialists and regular follow-up appointments. The main difference is in the formatting and slight variations in wording, but the content and medical information are consistent across both notes.

**Chief Complaint:** Worsening chronic hypertension

**History of Present Illness:**  
The patient presents for evaluation of worsening chronic hypertension. The patient has been on hydrochlorothiazide and Valsartan for 10 years. Recently, the patient's systolic blood pressure has been exceeding 200 mmHg, leading to an emergency department visit for headache and malaise. The patient was treated and discharged but returned 5 days later with difficulty finding words, blurred vision, and tingling in the lower extremities. On presentation, the blood pressure was 216/81 mmHg. Despite medical therapy, including five antihypertensive agents and an esmolol infusion, the blood pressure remained refractory.

**Workup and Findings:**  
- No acute intracranial process or carotid stenosis was found.
- Echocardiography showed mild concentric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved ejection fraction.
- Renal artery ultrasound indicated renal artery stenosis with flow at the arterial origin measuring 350 cm/s on the right and 208 cm/s on the left.
- Vascular surgery consultation revealed weak but palpable femoral pulses and an audible abdominal aortic bruit. Ankle-brachial index measurements were deferred, and an angiogram was scheduled.

- CTA confirmed stenosis 1.3 cm proximal to the celiac origin measuring 5 mm.

The patient will be consulted with other specialists to develop a comprehensive management plan. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the condition and adjust treatment as needed.
